topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Sachin opens with optimism about a new era for internet writers enabled by subscriptions, and Lenny introduces the episode and Sachin’s background (Substack head of product; ex-Facebook; founded Cocoon).

topics.title: Sponsor Break: Retool and Stytch
topics.summary: Lenny reads sponsor messages for Retool (building internal tools fast) and Stytch (authentication and onboarding).

topics.title: Sachin’s path from Cocoon to Substack
topics.summary: Sachin explains Cocoon’s origins (private photo sharing) and how frustrations with ad-driven models led to Substack’s subscription-first philosophy, culminating in Cocoon’s acquisition and his role leading product/design.

topics.title: Substack product org structure and evolution
topics.summary: Sachin describes Substack’s shift from no PMs to a product-driven org with PMs and full-stack teams, organized around writer, reader, and growth teams plus a systems team.

topics.title: Working with a product-strong founder
topics.summary: Sachin shares how he built trust with Substack’s CEO by acting as a facilitator, improving alignment/communication, and “catching up” to the founder’s long-held vision while integrating new data and perspectives.

topics.title: Scaling pains and who thrives in hypergrowth
topics.summary: They discuss the challenge of constantly changing processes as the company scales, and the personality fit required to be comfortable with ambiguity and frequent reinvention.

topics.title: Facebook vs Substack: prioritization and trade-offs
topics.summary: Sachin contrasts big-company PM work (permanent trade-offs and competing surfaces) with startup sequencing (time as the main constraint) and Substack’s evolution from tool to network with important order-of-operations decisions.

topics.title: Principles and north star: control for writers/readers
topics.summary: Sachin explains Substack’s principle-driven prioritization: maximizing writer and reader control/agency versus ad-driven algorithmic feeds, and how that principle shapes product choices.

topics.title: Recommendations feature: origin, skepticism, and impact
topics.summary: They unpack how recommendations emerged from organic discovery behaviors, why Substack chose writer-curated recommendations over algorithmic “you might like,” Chris’s initial skepticism, and the resulting viral loop and growth impact (millions of subs; network-driven subs).

topics.title: Sponsor Break: Vanta
topics.summary: Lenny reads a sponsor message for Vanta, focused on automating SOC 2 and security compliance for startups.

topics.title: Product rollout approach: pilots and Product Lab
topics.summary: Sachin describes Substack’s “build with writers/readers” approach: piloting major changes with a small set of writers, learning before broad rollout, and creating an invite-only Product Lab for rapid feedback and iteration.

topics.title: Handling press cycles and staying focused
topics.summary: Sachin explains how the team filters signal from noise, avoids distraction from media chatter, and keeps shipping—drawing on lessons from Facebook’s intense press environment.

topics.title: Substack’s future: writer tools, community, reader apps
topics.summary: Sachin outlines Substack’s roadmap: making it easier to start and monetize, supporting multiple formats (writing/podcasts/video) and community features, and building a reader-first experience via iOS/Android apps as an alternative to algorithmic feeds.

topics.title: Advice for new writers: start and iterate
topics.summary: Sachin encourages creators to simply start, publish a few posts (any format), and begin collecting subscribers—especially to reduce dependence on other platforms—while Lenny reinforces that this approach worked for him.
